ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: At any time in the last X weeks have you deliberately harmed or injured yourself or attempted suicide?
Notes: 0= No; 1= Yes; -1= Missing; -2= Refused to Answer; -3= Not Applicable

ElementDescription: How many times have you deliberately harmed or injured yourself or attempted suicide in the last X weeks?
INTERVIEWER: HOW RELIABLE IS THIS NUMBER?
Notes: 0= Unreliable; 2= Somewhat Reliable; 3= Reliable; -1= Missing; -2= Refused to Answer; -3= Not Applicable

ElementDescription: HOW MANY EPISODES WERE COUNTED AS THRESHOLD SUICIDE ATTEMPT/INTENTIONAL SELFINJURY?
Suicide Attempt
Notes: 0= No; 1= Yes; -1= Missing; -2= Refused to Answer; -3= Not Applicable

ElementDescription: Date of Suicide Episode
Method of Suicide
Did subject receive medical treatment?
Notes: 0= No; 1= Yes; -1= Missing; -2= Refused to Answer; -3= Not Applicable

ElementDescription: SASII SEQUENCE NUMBER
BASIS FOR SEQUENCE NUMBER
Notes: 1 = All episodes; 2 = All medically treated episodes; 3 = Most serious episode; 4 = First episode; 5 = Most recent episode; 6 = most serious last year; 7 = Other

ElementDescription: Think back to the most recent time (time before that) when you harmed yourself. Was this a single event or a series or cluster of events?
DESCRIBE BASIS FOR LABELING AS A CLUSTER: (Must be filled out if cluster. If not cluster, write -3 here.)
Was the initiation of your action to (method)/(self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose) deliberate, accidental, or somewhere in between?
Exact/estimated number of suicide attempts or self-harm events in this cluster.
First date of cluster (IF SINGLE EVENT ENTER DATE OF EVENT)
Last date of cluster (IF SINGLE EVENT ENTER DATE OF EVENT.)
How accurate is this date?
Notes: 1=Exact; 2=Within two weeks; 3=Within one month; 4=Anytime in last year

ElementDescription: Before we try to understand what led up to and followed your self-injury/attempted suicide/overdose, I want to first understand exactly what you did. Tell me again/describe exactly what method(s) you used to injure yourself?

What were you drinking?
Notes: 1 = BEER; 2 = WINE; 3 = LIQUOR; 4 = COMBINATION OF 1 and 2; 5 = COMBINATION OF 1 and 3; 6 = COMBINATION OF 2 and 3; 7 = COMBINATION OF 1, 2, and 3; 8= OTHER

VERIFICATION BY BRUISE/SWELLING?

What did you stop doing?
Notes: 1= STOPPED NEEDED MEDICAL TREATMENTS; 2= STOPPED MEDICATIONS; 3=OTHER

ElementDescription: If noted other stop medication, please specify:
For how long was the treatment/medication stopped (hours)?
What was the treatment for?
What were expected consequences of stopping treatment:
Transportation related injury (e.g., drove car off a cliff).
describe: Transportation related injury (e.g., drove car off a cliff).
Stepped into traffic.
describe: Stepped into traffic.
Other (describe):
INTERVIEWER: RATE MEDICAL RISK OF DEATH BASED ON METHOD AND ON OTHER SUBSTANCES PRESENT AT TIME
Notes: 1= Very Low; 2= Low; 3= Moderate; 4= High; 5= Very High; 6= Severe

ElementDescription: At the time of your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose, what final outcome did you most intend and expect? (RECORD ANSWER VERBATIM.)
INTERVIEWER: RATE SUBJECTS CONSCIOUS INTENT TO CAUSE SELF-INJURY, I.E., DEGREE THAT BEHAVIOR WAS INITIATED AND PERFORMED IN ORDER TO CAUSE SELF-INJURY OR IN ORDER TO RISK SELF-INJURY.
Notes: 0 = No bodily or physiological harm intended or expected (e.g., expected to fly from window ledge; habitual substance abuser expected to get high as usual; bulimic expected to purge as usual); 1 = Ambivalent intent to cause bodily injury or physiological harm to self and took a chance (e.g., Russian roulette, habitual substance abuser took more than normal amount); 2 = Clear expectations of some bodily injury, physiological harm to self (e.g., expected to sleep for a whole weekend, expected skin to be broken, bulimic expected to disrupt electrolyte balance), or death

ElementDescription: Just before or at the time of this self-injury/overdose, were you thinking about suicide or wishing you were dead?
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = I was wishing I was dead, but the thought of suicide did not go thru my mind; 2 = The thought of suicide passed thru my mind; 3 = I briefly considered it, but not seriously; 4 = I was thinking about it and was somewhat serious; 5 = I was very serious about dying but was also somewhat ambivalent; 6 = I was extremely serious, intended to die and was not ambivalent at all

ElementDescription: At the time it occurred, did you consider the episode a suicide attempt, even if you did not really intend to die?
Do you now consider that episode a suicide attempt?
What accounts for this change?
INTERVIEWER: RATE SUBJECTS CONSCIOUS EXPECTATION OF FATAL OUTCOME.
Notes: 0 = No expectation; 1 = Uncertain of outcome; 2 = Clear expectations of fatal outcome

ElementDescription: At the time or near the time of this episode, did you tell anyone, directly or indirectly, that you were thinking of suicide or that you wished you were dead?
Please describe this episode:
At the time or near the time of this episode, did you threaten suicide to anyone or do anything that could be or was interpreted by someone else as a threat to harm or kill yourself?
Please describe this episode:
Did you plan your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose, or was it an impulsive act?
Please describe this episode:
INTERVIEWER: RATE IMPULSIVITY OF ACT.
Notes: 1 = Commitment to act, followed by very careful or elaborate plan carried out over a period of time; 2 = Actively planned and/or got implements. Had impulse, resisted for days, then acted; 3 = Actively planned and/or got implements. Had impulse, resisted for less than 24 hours; 4 = No active planning. Had impulse, resisted for days, then acted; 5 = No active planning. Had impulse, resisted for less than 24 hours, then acted; 6 = No active planning. Occurred impulsively, with no forethought and without very strong emotion; 7 = No active planning. Occurred impulsively, with no forethought and with very strong emotion

ElementDescription: At the time or near the time of this episode, did you write a suicide note?
Did you arrange your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose in such a way that it would be difficult for anyone to find, stop, or save you?
Describe the circumstances:
INTERVIEWER: RATE PROBABILITY OF INTERVENTION BASED ON ALL INFORMATION
Notes: 1 = Chance of intervention remote. Act committed by person in a solitary or isolated place without access to telephone; 2 = Improbable intervention. Act committed by person alone, with intervention by a passerby possible although not expected; 3 = Ambiguous chance of intervention. Act committed by person alone, with no certainty of immediate assistance. However, a reasonable chance for intervention existed; 4 = Probable intervention. Act committed with another person in the immediate vicinity but not visibly. Or made phone call but did not directly communicate intention; 5 = Certain intervention. Act committed in the presence of another person/made phone call immediately before or after in order to advise of act or to say good-bye

ElementDescription: Following your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose were you taken to any of these places or did you turn to any of these places or people for help? Physician/Nurse (visit)

Following your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose were you taken to any of these places or did you turn to any of these places or people for help? Crisis outreach/after hours team/mental health professional (In person visit)
Following your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose were you taken to any of these places or did you turn to any of these places or people for help? Police/wellness check (At home or other residence)

Following your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose were you taken to any of these places or did you turn to any of these places or people for help? Paramedics/ambulance/aid car (At home or other residence)
Following your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose were you taken to any of these places or did you turn to any of these places or people for help? Hospital emergency room
Hospital emergency room: were you medically treated?
Following your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose were you taken to any of these places or did you turn to any of these places or people for help? Inpatient, psychiatric unit
Inpatient, psychiatric unit: Number of Days
Inpatient, psychiatric unit:Was this voluntary?
Notes: 1= Yes; 2= voluntary but threatened with legal commitment if not agreed to; 3= legally detained on a 24 to 48 hr hold; 4= 72 or more hour hold)

ElementDescription: Following your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose were you taken to any of these places or did you turn to any of these places or people for help? Hospital medical floor
Hospital medical floor: Number of Days
Following your self-injury/suicide attempt/overdose were you taken to any of these places or did you turn to any of these places or people for help? Intensive care
Intensive care: Number of Days
What was your physical condition afterward?
RECORD INFORMATION FROM MEDICAL RECORDS
INTERVIEWER: RATE PHYSICAL CONDITION FOLLOWING EPISODE
Notes: 0= No Effect; 1= Very Mild Effect; 2= Mild Effect; 3= Moderate Effect; 4= Severe Effect; 5= Very Severe Effect; 6= Extremely Severe Effect; 7= Lethal Effect

ElementDescription: INTERVIEWER: USE ALL APPROPRIATE INFORMATION REGARDING TREATMENT THAT HAS BEEN GATHERED THROUGHOUT INTERVIEW TO CODE HIGHEST APPLICABLE NUMBER FROM LIST BELOW
Notes: 0 = No medical treatment sought/required; 1 = Went to emergency room or physician, had no medical treatment or assessment and went home; 2 = Went directly to an in-patient psychiatric unit; 3 = Medically treated while on in-patient psychiatric unit, without going to emergency room; 4 = Went to emergency room or physician, was medically treated and went home; 5 = Went to emergency room, was treated and admitted to psychiatry unit; 6 = While on psychiatric unit, went to emergency room for medical treatment and then returned to psychiatric unit; 7 = Admitted to medical unit, whether or not via emergency room, for observation (hours to overnight); 8 = Admitted to medical unit, whether or not via emergency room, for required treatment; 9 = Admitted to intensive care unit, whether or not via emergency room or medical floor; 10 = Mortuary

ElementDescription: INTERVIEWER: RATE SUBJECTS INTENT TO DIE, I.E., THE SERIOUSNESS OR INTENSITY OF THE WISH TO TERMINATE HIS OR HER OWN LIFE. RATINGS SHOULD REFLECT YOUR BEST ESTIMATE BASED ON ALL INFORMATION. (24a description must be filled out if there was intent. If no intent, write -3 in the description space.)
Notes: 1 = Obviously no intent; 2 = Only minimal intent; 3 = Definite intent but very ambivalent; 4 = Serious intent; 5 = Extreme intent (careful planning and every expectation of death)

ElementDescription: DESCRIBE REASON FOR RATING:
INTERVIEWER: BASED ON DEFINITION OF SASII ON APPENDIX, CATEGORIZE BEHAVIOR. CODING SHOULD REFLECT YOUR BEST JUDGMENT BASED ON ALL INFORMATION.
Notes: 1 = Accidental self-harm, without undue risk taking and without unreasonable expectation of safety; 2 = Accidental self-harm, with undue risk taking or with unreasonable expectation of safety; 3 = Victim-precipitated self-harm, without intent to be harmed by others but with undue risk taking or with unreasonable expectation of safety; 4 = Victim-precipitated self-harm with intent to be harmed by other; 5 = Intentional self-injury, but not a suicide attempt; 6 = Ambivalent suicide attempt; 7 = Suicide attempt with no ambivalence; 8 = Suicide attempt that is a failed suicide, with continued life purely accidental and a near miracle; 9 = OTHER, including absence of a behavior, which results in harm or illness

ElementDescription: Visit name
